content.user_instructions:

```Follow the instructions below naturally, without repeating, referencing, echoing, or mirroring any of their wording!

All the following instructions should guide your behavior silently and must never influence the wording of your message in an explicit or meta way!

Be precise and comprehensive in your analysis. Don't sugar-coat responses. Be as objective as possible. Critique and question my views if necessary. Take a forward-thinking view.

Define highly technical or specialized abbreviations in full before using them.```

parts:
Do a very concise summary (no proofs, no explanations needed) for the formulae used in:
- One sample hypothesis testing of mean, Z-test and t-test
- One sample hypothesis testing of proportion using Z-test
- Two independent sample t-test under equal population variance assumption
- Two independent proportions Z-test
- Paired sample t-test
Include in each hypothesis testing case the formula for a symmetric (1-alpha)% confidence interval

thoughts.summary: Providing formulae for hypothesis tests and symmetric CI
thoughts.content: I’ll provide concise formulas for hypothesis tests and confidence intervals (CI). For a one-sample mean, I’ll cover the Z-test (when σ is known or n is large) and the t-test (when σ is unknown). Also, I’ll include notation, test statistics, degrees of freedom, and critical values for both symmetric CI and hypothesis testing. I'll mention the one-sample proportion test too, with the appropriate formulas.
chunks: I’ll provide concise formulas for hypothesis tests and confidence intervals (CI).
For a one-sample mean, I’ll cover the Z-test (when σ is known or n is large) and the t-test (when σ is unknown).
Also, I’ll include notation, test statistics, degrees of freedom, and critical values for both symmetric CI and hypothesis testing.
I'll mention the one-sample proportion test too, with the appropriate formulas.

thoughts.summary: Providing formulas for t-test and proportions Z-test
thoughts.content:
For the two independent sample t-test with equal variances, the formula for the pooled variance is Sp^2, and the test statistic is t. The degrees of freedom are df = n1 + n2 - 2. The confidence interval (CI) for the difference is given with the t critical value.

For the two independent proportions Z-test, I’ll explain the pooled estimate for testing equality (H0: p1 = p2), and CI with unpooled estimate if Δ0 is not 0, using standard error formulas.
chunks: For the two independent sample t-test with equal variances, the formula for the pooled variance is Sp^2, and the test statistic is t.
The degrees of freedom are df = n1 + n2 - 2.
The confidence interval (CI) for the difference is given with the t critical value.
For the two independent proportions Z-test, I’ll explain the pooled estimate for testing equality (H0: p1 = p2), and CI with unpooled estimate if Δ0 is not 0, using standard error formulas.

thoughts.summary: Providing concise formulas for hypothesis tests and CIs
thoughts.content: For the paired-sample t-test, I will give the difference formula (di = xi - yi), the test statistic, degrees of freedom (df), and the CI formula. I’ll include one-sample mean t-test and Z-test formulas, depending on known standard deviations. I’ll also provide the critical values and note notations for symmetric confidence intervals.
chunks: For the paired-sample t-test, I will give the difference formula (di = xi - yi), the test statistic, degrees of freedom (df), and the CI formula.
I’ll include one-sample mean t-test and Z-test formulas, depending on known standard deviations.
I’ll also provide the critical values and note notations for symmetric confidence intervals.

parts:
**Notation:**  
\(\bar x\)=sample mean, \(s\)=sample SD, \(n\)=sample size.  
For proportions: \(x\)=#successes, \(\hat p=x/n\).  
Critical values: \(z_{\alpha/2}=\Phi^{-1}(1-\alpha/2)\), \(t_{\alpha/2,\nu}=\) upper \((\alpha/2)\)-quantile of \(t\) with \(\nu\) df.

---

## 1) One-sample mean: Z-test (known \(\sigma\))
\(H_0:\mu=\mu_0\)

\[
z=\frac{\bar x-\mu_0}{\sigma/\sqrt{n}}
\quad(\text{two-sided reject if }|z|>z_{\alpha/2})
\]

Symmetric \((1-\alpha)\) CI:
\[
\bar x \pm z_{\alpha/2}\frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}
\]

---

## 2) One-sample mean: t-test (unknown \(\sigma\))
\(H_0:\mu=\mu_0,\ \nu=n-1\)

\[
t=\frac{\bar x-\mu_0}{s/\sqrt{n}}
\quad(\text{two-sided reject if }|t|>t_{\alpha/2,\nu})
\]

Symmetric \((1-\alpha)\) CI:
\[
\bar x \pm t_{\alpha/2,n-1}\frac{s}{\sqrt{n}}
\]

---

## 3) One-sample proportion: Z-test
\(H_0:p=p_0\)

\[
z=\frac{\hat p-p_0}{\sqrt{p_0(1-p_0)/n}}
\quad(\text{two-sided reject if }|z|>z_{\alpha/2})
\]

Symmetric \((1-\alpha)\) CI (Wald):
\[
\hat p \pm z_{\alpha/2}\sqrt{\frac{\hat p(1-\hat p)}{n}}
\]

---

## 4) Two independent samples: t-test, equal variances (pooled)
\(H_0:\mu_1-\mu_2=\Delta_0,\ \nu=n_1+n_2-2\)

\[
s_p^2=\frac{(n_1-1)s_1^2+(n_2-1)s_2^2}{n_1+n_2-2},\quad
t=\frac{(\bar x_1-\bar x_2)-\Delta_0}{s_p\sqrt{\frac1{n_1}+\frac1{n_2}}}
\]
(two-sided reject if \(|t|>t_{\alpha/2,\nu}\))

Symmetric \((1-\alpha)\) CI for \(\mu_1-\mu_2\):
\[
(\bar x_1-\bar x_2)\pm t_{\alpha/2,n_1+n_2-2}\; s_p\sqrt{\frac1{n_1}+\frac1{n_2}}
\]

---

## 5) Two independent proportions: Z-test (equality)
\(H_0:p_1=p_2\)

\[
\hat p_1=\frac{x_1}{n_1},\ \hat p_2=\frac{x_2}{n_2},\ 
\hat p=\frac{x_1+x_2}{n_1+n_2}
\]
\[
z=\frac{\hat p_1-\hat p_2}{\sqrt{\hat p(1-\hat p)\left(\frac1{n_1}+\frac1{n_2}\right)}}
\quad(\text{two-sided reject if }|z|>z_{\alpha/2})
\]

Symmetric \((1-\alpha)\) CI for \(p_1-p_2\) (unpooled Wald):
\[
(\hat p_1-\hat p_2)\pm z_{\alpha/2}\sqrt{\frac{\hat p_1(1-\hat p_1)}{n_1}+\frac{\hat p_2(1-\hat p_2)}{n_2}}
\]

---

## 6) Paired sample t-test
Differences \(d_i=x_i-y_i\), \(\bar d\)=mean of differences, \(s_d\)=SD of differences, \(n\)=#pairs, \(\nu=n-1\).  
\(H_0:\mu_d=\mu_{d0}\) (often \(\mu_{d0}=0\))

\[
t=\frac{\bar d-\mu_{d0}}{s_d/\sqrt{n}}
\quad(\text{two-sided reject if }|t|>t_{\alpha/2,\nu})
\]

Symmetric \((1-\alpha)\) CI for \(\mu_d\):
\[
\bar d \pm t_{\alpha/2,n-1}\frac{s_d}{\sqrt{n}}
\]

```latex
\documentclass[9pt]{extarticle}
\usepackage{graphicx,amsmath,amssymb,physics}

\title{Hypothesis Testing and Confidence Intervals}

\begin{document}

\maketitle

\noindent
\textbf{Notation.}
$\bar x$ = sample mean, $s$ = sample standard deviation, $n$ = sample size.\\
For proportions: $x$ = number of successes, $\hat p=x/n$.\\
Critical values: $z_{\alpha/2}=\Phi^{-1}(1-\alpha/2)$, and $t_{\alpha/2,\nu}$ is the upper $(\alpha/2)$-quantile of the $t$ distribution with $\nu$ degrees of freedom.

\bigskip

\section*{1. One-sample mean: $Z$-test (known $\sigma$)}
\noindent
\textbf{Hypotheses:} $H_0:\mu=\mu_0$ (two-sided alternative $H_1:\mu\neq\mu_0$).\\[4pt]
\textbf{Test statistic:}
\[
z=\frac{\bar x-\mu_0}{\sigma/\sqrt{n}}
\qquad
(\text{two-sided reject if }|z|>z_{\alpha/2}).
\]
\textbf{Symmetric $(1-\alpha)$ confidence interval:}
\[
\bar x \pm z_{\alpha/2}\frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}.
\]

\bigskip

\section*{2. One-sample mean: $t$-test (unknown $\sigma$)}
\noindent
\textbf{Hypotheses:} $H_0:\mu=\mu_0$ (two-sided alternative $H_1:\mu\neq\mu_0$).\\
\textbf{Degrees of freedom:} $\nu=n-1$.\\[4pt]
\textbf{Test statistic:}
\[
t=\frac{\bar x-\mu_0}{s/\sqrt{n}}
\qquad
(\text{two-sided reject if }|t|>t_{\alpha/2,\nu}).
\]
\textbf{Symmetric $(1-\alpha)$ confidence interval:}
\[
\bar x \pm t_{\alpha/2,n-1}\frac{s}{\sqrt{n}}.
\]

\bigskip

\section*{3. One-sample proportion: $Z$-test}
\noindent
\textbf{Hypotheses:} $H_0:p=p_0$ (two-sided alternative $H_1:p\neq p_0$).\\[4pt]
\textbf{Test statistic:}
\[
z=\frac{\hat p-p_0}{\sqrt{p_0(1-p_0)/n}}
\qquad
(\text{two-sided reject if }|z|>z_{\alpha/2}).
\]
\textbf{Symmetric $(1-\alpha)$ confidence interval (Wald):}
\[
\hat p \pm z_{\alpha/2}\sqrt{\frac{\hat p(1-\hat p)}{n}}.
\]

\bigskip

\section*{4. Two independent samples: $t$-test, equal variances (pooled)}
\noindent
\textbf{Hypotheses:} $H_0:\mu_1-\mu_2=\Delta_0$ (two-sided alternative $H_1:\mu_1-\mu_2\neq \Delta_0$).\\
\textbf{Degrees of freedom:} $\nu=n_1+n_2-2$.\\[4pt]
\textbf{Pooled variance:}
\[
s_p^2=\frac{(n_1-1)s_1^2+(n_2-1)s_2^2}{n_1+n_2-2}.
\]
\textbf{Test statistic:}
\[
t=\frac{(\bar x_1-\bar x_2)-\Delta_0}{s_p\sqrt{\frac1{n_1}+\frac1{n_2}}}
\qquad
(\text{two-sided reject if }|t|>t_{\alpha/2,\nu}).
\]
\textbf{Symmetric $(1-\alpha)$ confidence interval for $\mu_1-\mu_2$:}
\[
(\bar x_1-\bar x_2)\pm t_{\alpha/2,n_1+n_2-2}\; s_p\sqrt{\frac1{n_1}+\frac1{n_2}}.
\]

\bigskip

\section*{5. Two independent proportions: $Z$-test (equality)}
\noindent
\textbf{Hypotheses:} $H_0:p_1=p_2$ (two-sided alternative $H_1:p_1\neq p_2$).\\[4pt]
\textbf{Sample proportions and pooled proportion:}
\[
\hat p_1=\frac{x_1}{n_1},\qquad \hat p_2=\frac{x_2}{n_2},\qquad
\hat p=\frac{x_1+x_2}{n_1+n_2}.
\]
\textbf{Test statistic:}
\[
z=\frac{\hat p_1-\hat p_2}{\sqrt{\hat p(1-\hat p)\left(\frac1{n_1}+\frac1{n_2}\right)}}
\qquad
(\text{two-sided reject if }|z|>z_{\alpha/2}).
\]
\textbf{Symmetric $(1-\alpha)$ confidence interval for $p_1-p_2$ (unpooled Wald):}
\[
(\hat p_1-\hat p_2)\pm z_{\alpha/2}\sqrt{\frac{\hat p_1(1-\hat p_1)}{n_1}+\frac{\hat p_2(1-\hat p_2)}{n_2}}.
\]

\bigskip

\section*{6. Paired sample $t$-test}
\noindent
Let $d_i=x_i-y_i$ be paired differences, $\bar d$ the mean of differences, $s_d$ the standard deviation of differences, and $n$ the number of pairs.\\
\textbf{Hypotheses:} $H_0:\mu_d=\mu_{d0}$ (often $\mu_{d0}=0$; two-sided alternative $H_1:\mu_d\neq \mu_{d0}$).\\
\textbf{Degrees of freedom:} $\nu=n-1$.\\[4pt]
\textbf{Test statistic:}
\[
t=\frac{\bar d-\mu_{d0}}{s_d/\sqrt{n}}
\qquad
(\text{two-sided reject if }|t|>t_{\alpha/2,\nu}).
\]
\textbf{Symmetric $(1-\alpha)$ confidence interval for $\mu_d$:}
\[
\bar d \pm t_{\alpha/2,n-1}\frac{s_d}{\sqrt{n}}.
\]

\end{document}
```
